The head of the UGC demanded action, and a [[Royal Commission]] was established by Act of Parliament in 1935 to look into the matter.<ref name=Watson2007 />
The commission recommended changes to the university's constitution, of which the most visible was the merger of the two Newcastle colleges to form King's College (originally to be called University College, Newcastle until the Durham colleges objected). The two divisions also gained permanent heads: the Rector of King's College and the Warden of the Durham Colleges, with the vice-chancellorship alternated between them (the legacy of this lives on, in that the executive head of the university is still called "the vice-chancellor and warden"). Convocation's veto was abolished and a [[University Court]] established, and academic appointments were made the responsibility of the central University.<ref name=Watson2007 /> The Senate was made responsible for granting degrees, which had previously been a function of Convocation. As a result, the ceremony at which degrees are conferred at Durham was separated from the meeting of Convocation and become known as Congregation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0001547/19430415/044/0002|date=15 April 1943|title=North Country Notes|work=Newcastle Journal|via=[[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
The new University Court set about fundraising for an expansion of the Durham division, with plans for new buildings for St Mary's College, the Student Union and the science laboratories. The importance of this expansion was emphasised by a fall in the number of students to the low 400s in 1939 due to cutbacks in teacher training, although Newcastle grew to 1500. In early 1939, permission was given to start work on the science site and the union, but this was cut short by the outbreak of the [[Second World War]].<ref name=Watson2007 />
By the end of 1940, the number of students in Durham had fallen to only 270, forcing Hatfield and University colleges to temporarily merge. But 1941 saw RAF cadets sent to Durham to study science – primarily maths, physics and mechanics – raising student numbers back to healthier levels. Newcastle, with its much larger student population, was much less affected than the Durham Colleges.<ref name=Watson2007 />
===Expansion after World War Two===
After the war, the Durham division expanded rapidly – the Warden, Sir [[James Fitzjames Duff|James Duff]], believing not only that growth was essential but that more accommodation was the necessary first step to growing the division. Durham had to be a residential university – it didn't have the local population to thrive otherwise. He planned to double the number of students in Durham to over 1000 in a decade. Under pressure from the UGC, this target was raised to 2000 in 1946. Newcastle was also constrained – at 1700 students it had reached what was felt to be the local capacity, and (like the other [[redbrick university|civic universities]]) would have to start looking further afield to attract students in order to reach its target of 3000.<ref name=Watson2007 />
1947 saw progress towards this goal. St Aidan's Society ([[St Aidan's College, Durham|St Aidan's College]] from 1965) was founded as the female counterpart to St Cuthbert's Society, catering for the non-resident "home student" women, and moved onto Shincliffe Hall; the foundation stone for the new [[St Mary's College, Durham|St. Mary's]] College building on Elvet Hill was laid by Princess Elizabeth (later Queen [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Elizabeth II]]); and plans for a new men's college (to become [[Grey College, Durham|Grey College]]) were approved by the Council of the Durham Colleges. In the same year, the College of the Venerable Bede (as St Bede's College had been renamed in 1935) became a constituent college of the university. [[Lumley Castle]] was also leased from 1945 to house students from University College. By 1948 the Durham division hit 1100 students – the growth in numbers outstripping the residential capacity of the university and leaving a third of students without College accommodation – while Newcastle had over 3200.<ref name=Watson2007 />
{{Quote|We badly underestimated the rate at which our numbers would increase after the war|author=Sir James Duff|source=1950, quoted in ''The Durham Difference''<ref name=Watson2007 />}}
St Mary's took five years to build, the new site finally opening in 1952. In the same year final approval was given to the establishment of a new men's college south of the river, linked with the expansion of the science site. However, although the UGC approved the plan, funds were not immediately available, however, and it was 1956 before financial approval was given and 1957 before building work began. The new college opened in 1959 as [[Grey College, Durham|Grey College]] – the name being chosen over Cromwell College by a single vote – but the main block was not completed until 1961.<ref name=Watson2007 /><ref name=GreyHistory>{{cite book|title=From the Ashes|author=Nigel Watson|year=2004|publisher=James & James (Publishers) Ltd.}}</ref>
Expansion also continued in other parts of the university. The West Building, for the departments of geography and mathematics, opened in 1952. Work on a new central admissions system, replacing the system whereby students applied to individual colleges, began in 1958. In the same year St John's College was formally divided into two closely linked parts: St John's Hall for University students and [[Cranmer Hall, Durham|Cranmer Hall]] for those preparing for ordination.<ref name="DF John's ">{{cite journal|journal=Durham First|volume=26|title=The First Lady of Cranmer Hall|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/durham.first/spring09/cranmer/|date=2009|accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref> 1960 saw the opening of the department of applied science. In 1961, St Aidan's Society moved into its new building and became St Aidan's College. Work on Dunelm House and Kingsgate Bridge started in 1962.<ref name=Watson2007 />
In 1960 the Council set a target of 3,000 students by the early 1970s, and in 1962 a target of 4,500 students by the early 1980s. Two more men's colleges (to become [[Van Mildert College]] and [[Collingwood College, Durham|Collingwood College]]) and a third women's college (to become [[Trevelyan College]]) were planned.<ref name=Watson2007 />
In 1946 the University College of the West Indies was established, affiliated to the University of London. In 1955 this became the [[University of the West Indies]] (UWI) and Codrington College stopped offering degrees except in theology.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HRGW7WsDzhgC&pg=PT85&lpg=PT85&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Afro-Greeks: Dialogues between Anglophone Caribbean Literature and Classics in the Twentieth Century|author=Emily Greenwood|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|date=28 January 2010|pages=84–85 and 369–370}}</ref> In 1965, Coddington became affiliated to the UWI and no longer offered undergraduate Durham degrees.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.codrington.org/cms/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=18&Itemid=1 |title=A Historical Overview of Codrington College |accessdate=1 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119173303/http://www.codrington.org/cms/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=18&Itemid=1 |archivedate=19 November 2015 |df= }}</ref> Codrington's affiliation to Durham was finally removed from the University Statutes on 13 July 2011.<ref name=Statutes2011>{{cite web|url=http://privycouncil.independent.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2011/07/orders-13july2011.pdf|publisher=[[Privy Council (UK)|Privy Council]]|date=13 July 2011|accessdate=1 November 2015|title=Orders approved at the Privy Council held by the Queen at Buckingham Palace on 13th July 2011}}</ref>
===Tensions between the Newcastle and Durham divisions===
In 1947, tensions had surfaced again over the Durham-Newcastle divide, with the growth in numbers meaning "the two divisions were acting as de facto universities".<ref name=Watson2007 /> Lord Percy, Rector of King's College, proposed that the university change its name to the 'University of Durham and Newcastle', with the divisions becoming 'Durham University' and 'Newcastle University'. This idea was defeated in [[Convocation]] (the assembly of members of the university) by 135 votes to 129.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Durham University Journal|page=121|volume=13–14|title=Name of the University|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Er4TAQAAMAAJ&q=%22university+of+durham+and+newcastle%22&dq=%22university+of+durham+and+newcastle%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAGoVChMIrqXugvCjyAIVy5qACh128AKN|publisher=Durham University}}</ref>
By the late 1950s, Durham had over 1,500 students and Newcastle 3,500. The academic board of the Newcastle division passed a resolution on 29 January 1960 calling for Newcastle to become an independent university:
{{Quote|the healthy development of the university now makes desirable the establishment of a University of Newcastle in place of King's College|author=Academic Board of the Newcastle Division of Durham University|source=quoted in ''The Durham Difference''<ref name=Watson2007 />}}
On 23 February 1960 the academic board of the Durham division gave their agreement and by June the Council of King's College and the Council of the Durham Colleges had both approved. The government and the UGC approved the plan on 21 July, and by May 1961 statutes had been drafted. The Universities of Durham and Newcastle upon Tyne Act received Royal assent on 10 July 1963, and on 1 August 1963 King's College became the [[Newcastle University|University of Newcastle upon Tyne]], leaving Durham University once more based solely in its home city.<ref name=Watson2007 /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://reed.dur.ac.uk/xtf/view?docId=ead/uni/unda.xml#UNDall-400|title=Statutes|work=Durham University Records: Foundation and Statutes|accessdate=29 October 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ncl.ac.uk/regulations/docs/statutes.pdf|title=University Statues – Newcastle University|accessdate=29 October 2015|publisher=[[Newcastle University]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705075412/http://www.ncl.ac.uk/regulations/docs/statutes.pdf#|archive-date=5 July 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1963/jul/10/royal-assent|date=10 July 1963|title=Royal Assent|publisher=Hansard|accessdate=29 October 2015}}</ref>
==Modern university 1963–99==
The university's new statutes abolished the court but maintained the title of Warden of the Durham Colleges, with the executive head of the university being the vice-chancellor and warden. In 1963, the university consisted of five council colleges (now styled maintained colleges), with a further three planned, St Cuthbert's Society, the three independent constituent colleges (now styled recognised colleges), and the two licensed halls (the women's teacher training colleges: St Hild's and Neville's Cross).<ref name=Watson2007 />
Expansion continued, with Grey College's third building opening in 1963. In 1964 the centralised admissions system went into operation. [[Van Mildert College]], the School of Engineering, the [[Durham Business School]], the Graduate Society (now [[Ustinov College]]), the Maiden Castle sports ground and a number of other academic departments all opened in 1965; and in the same year the BEd degree was introduced for students at the teacher training colleges. [[Trevelyan College]] and the new buildings for St Aidan's College opened in 1966. The [[Durham University Botanic Garden|botanic garden]] moved to its current site in 1970.<ref name=DUBG /> Construction of new residences for University College in Durham also meant Lumley Castle could finally be given up in 1970.<ref name=Watson2007 />
[[Sierra Leone]] had gained its independence in 1961, and in 1967 the government established the [[University of Sierra Leone]]. Fourah Bay College joined Njala University College to form the new University and ended its affiliation with Durham.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blackpast.org/gah/fourah-bay-college-1827|title= Fourah Bay College|work=Online Encyclopedia of Significant People and Places in Global African History|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
In 1963, Neville's Cross College became mixed,<ref name=NCC /> and in 1966 Cranmer Hall in St John's College became the first Anglican theological college in the world to train women for ordination.<ref name="DF John's " /> The [[Roman Catholic]] [[seminary]] of [[Ushaw College]], which had been located in [[Ushaw Moor]] near Durham since 1808, was licensed as a hall of residence in 1968. St Chad's Hall stopped training for the Anglican priesthood in 1972, and in 1976 changed its name to St Chad's College.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://reed.dur.ac.uk/xtf/view?docId=ead/uni/undf.xml#UNDall-3476|title=St Chad's College|work=Durham University Records: Colleges|accessdate=30 October 2015}}</ref>
In 1965 the sports hall at Maiden Castle opened and in 1966 Dunelm House was finally completed, providing centralised student facilities and a home for the Student Representative Council and the Athletics Union moved in. In 1969 the Statutes were amended to give the president of the Student Representative Council a seat on the University Council.<ref name=Watson2007 /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/resources/university.calendar/volumei/2003.2004/statutes/stat8.pdf|title=The Council|work=Statutes of the University of Durham|date=2003|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref> In 1970 the Student Representative Council became Durham Student Union.<ref name=DSU />
In the 1970s the reorganisation of teacher training by the government threatened the existence of the three teacher training colleges. In 1975 St Hild's College and the College of the Venerable Bede merged to form the [[College of St Hild and St Bede]], remaining a Recognised College and teaching a university-validated BEd. This lasted until 1979 when it surrendered its autonomy to become a Maintained College of the university, with all teacher training being transferred to the university's School of Education.<ref name=HildBede /> Neville's Cross College merged with Durham Technical College in 1977, leaving the university and forming [[New College Durham]].<ref name=NCC />
Following the lowering of the [[age of majority]] from 21 to 18 in 1970, meaning universities were no longer ''in loco parentis'', Van Mildert became the first maintained college to go mixed in 1971, with some students transferring in from other colleges that year followed by a full intake in 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/van-mildert.college/about/history/crest/|title= Building the College|publisher=Van Mildert College|accessdate=4 December 2015}}</ref> This was followed in 1972 by the opening of [[Collingwood College, Durham|Collingwood College]] as the first purpose-built mixed college, and the first university residence in the UK to have men's and women's rooms in the same blocks.<ref name=Watson2007 /> In 1973 St John's College went fully mixed, admitting women to St John's Hall.<ref name="DF John's " />
St Aidan's decided to become mixed in 1978, with the first men entering in 1981 – the first of the Women's colleges to do so. This was followed by Grey JCR voting to go mixed in 1983, and the College governing board ratifying the decision. Some women students who had not won places at other colleges were admitted in 1984 and the first full intake was in 1985.<ref name=GreyHistory /> Decisions by college governing boards and the University Council in 1986 led to the final three men's colleges going mixed, in some cases against the wishes of the students: University College in 1987, and Hatfield and St Chad's in 1988.<ref name=Watson2007 /><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.castlealumni.uk/files/castellum/Castellum%252039%2520(1986).pdf|journal=Castellum|volume=39|date=1986|title=Master's Letter|pages=1–2}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In October 1987, Trevelyan's governing body voted to go mixed despite the JCR voting to remain women-only. The first men were admitted in 1990.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dWeZwQmKV2IC&pg=PA146&f=false#v=onepage&q&f=false|pages=146–151|title=Trevs: A Celebration of 40 Years|publisher=Roundtuit Publishing|date=2006|author=Susan Martin}}</ref>
In 1986 Durham Castle and Cathedral were made a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] in the first group of sites recognised in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.durhamworldheritagesite.com/heritage|publisher=Durham World Heritage Site|title=What is Durham World Heritage Site?|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref> This was extended in 2008 to cover Palace Green and the surrounding buildings.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.durhamworldheritagesite.com/heritage/site-boundaries|publisher=Durham World Heritage Site|title=Site Boundaries: An Evolving Definition of Heritage|accessdate=31 October 2015}}</ref>
In 1987 the perception still existed that the university was too small. The student population was limited to 5000 (4936 in 1987), and had only grown by 200 over the previous 5 years. The Senate noted in May 1988 that expansion was desirable, but that it would be more cost effective, and less risky to do this by making "more intensive use … of the present facilities" rather than establishing a new College.<ref name=Stockton>{{cite book|url=http://oxcheps.new.ox.ac.uk/MainSite%20pages/Resources/OxCHEPS_OP3.pdf|title=Breaking the Mould: The Surprising Story of Stockton|author=John Hayward|date=2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://reed.dur.ac.uk/xtf/view?docId=ead/uni/undf.xml#UNDall-6556|title=Howlands Trust Project|work=Durham University Records: Colleges|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> By 1990 numbers had reached 5,908 and by 1995, 9,717 in Durham City or 10,436 including Stockton (see below) – doubling the population in under ten years.<ref name="Durham Masterplan"/>
In 1988 the [[Wesley Study Centre]] opened within St John's College as a training centre for Methodist ministers, forming a unique ecumenical partnership with Cranmer Hall to train Anglican and Methodist ministers alongside each other.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/wsc.online/wp-content/uploads/2012/02/Wesley-Study-Centre-Prospectus3.pdf|title=Wesley Study Centre Prospectus|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
In 1989 the university started its fund-raising and [[alumni]] office, with a virtual community for alumni<ref>http://www.dunelm.org.uk dunelm.org.uk</ref> and several large gifts made to the university, including for the Centre for Middle Eastern Studies, the [[Durham University Department of Physics|Department of Physics]] and the [[Wolfson Research Institute]].
1990 saw the opening of the [[Teikyo University of Japan in Durham]], an overseas campus of [[Teikyo University]] in [[Japan]], by [[Katharine, Duchess of Kent]].<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.teikyo-u.ac.jp/english/pdf/english_guide.pdf|publisher=Teikyo University|page=4|title=Global Guide Book|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/hr/applicants/about/highlights/|title=Historical Highlights|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref>
From 1993 to 1997 the university attempted unsuccessfully to raise funds for a new college at Howlands Farm. In 1997 the decision was made to instead build postgraduate accommodation on the site under the management of the existing Graduate Society.<ref name=Stockton />
In 1994, Durham was one of the founder members of the [[1994 Group]] of smaller research-intensive universities, set up in response to the establishment of the [[Russell Group]].
===Development in Stockton===
The idea of Durham University establishing a presence on Teesside was first floated in 1987 and planning began in earnest in 1988 for a "Birkbeck of the North" with around 1,000 students. Teesside was, at that time, the largest conurbation in Europe without a university, and the [[Teesside Development Corporation]] had recently been established to try to regenerate the area. In April 1989 a formal announcement was made that Teesside Polytechnic and Durham University were working together "in planning a major development in Higher Education in Cleveland and its adjacent areas". <ref name=Stockton />
Stresses in the partnership arise in December 1989, when Durham approved plans for a new Institute of Health Studies without discussions with the Polytechnic. This led in January 1990 to a formula establishing the development as a Joint University College between Durham and Teesside rather than (as originally conceived) a Durham college with backing from Teesside. This was approved by Senate in mid February and the initiative was launched publicly three days later.<ref name=Stockton />
The initial bid to the funding councils (the Universities Funding Council – UFC; and the Polytechnics and Colleges Funding Council – PCFC) was for 280 students initially, rising to 840 after three years. In 1991 the UFC and PCFC agreed to fund 100 places each initially, rising to 225 each – only half of what had been hoped for. Nevertheless, plans went ahead and a site opposite [[Stockton-on-Tees]] on the south bank of the river was chosen. The Joint University College on Teesside (JUCOT) was formally launched on 3 September 1991 by [[Michael Fallon]], Schools Minister and MP for Darlington.<ref name=Stockton />
On 1 January 1992, Robert Parfitt was appointed as the first Principal of the College. Later that year Durham's statutes were modified to allow it grant joint degrees, regulations for the degrees to be awarded by JUCOT were established, and JUCOT was formally incorporated as a Limited Company established under a joint venture agreement between Durham and Teesside. The name did not, however, prove acceptable to the various government departments, nor was the alternative of Queen's College (there were too many already), but the name of University College, Stockton was approved just before opening on 12 October 1992 with an initial enrolment of 190 students.<ref name=Stockton />
Near the end of is first year of operation, the College was formally opened by [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]] on 18 May 1993. The 1993 academic year saw student numbers grow to 430 with the addition of teacher training. In 1994, at the suggestion of the UCS board, Durham assumed administrative and financial responsibility for the College. At the same time, approval was given to build student residences at Stockton, and the Privy Council approved changes to Durham's statutes making UCS a residential and teaching college of the university.<ref name=Watson2007 /><ref name=Stockton /><ref>{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20041016085906/http://www.dur.ac.uk/about/history/qcs.php|archive-date=16 October 2004|url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/about/history/qcs.php|title=Foundation of Queen's Campus}}</ref>
Parfitt retired in April 1994 and was replaced as Principal by John Hayward. Integration with Durham began, with the departments being established as Boards of Studies, and the company being wound up – its Board of Directors becoming (like Durham colleges) a Board of Governors, still including Teesside but with increased representation from Durham.<ref name=Stockton />
In 1996 it was agreed that students at Stockton would take degrees of Durham from 1998, rather than the joint degrees that had been awarded previously. With Durham taking on sole responsibility in 1998, the campus was renamed the University of Durham, Stockton Campus (UDSC), separating teaching responsibilities from UCS.<ref name=Watson2007 /><ref name=Stockton /> <!-- A curious fact about Queen's Campus, Stockton, is that it is located on the south bank of the [[River Tees]] within [[Thornaby-on-Tees]] and not in Stockton at all. For centuries the Tees formed the historical division between the [[Historic counties of England|historic counties]] of [[Yorkshire]] and Durham, with Thornaby-on-Tees being one of the most northern towns in Yorkshire. With the creation of the county borough of [[Teesside]] in 1968 areas both north and south of the river were removed from their administrative counties. Teesside itself was engulfed into the County of [[Cleveland, England|Cleveland]] in 1974. Yet another local government change in 1996 saw the breakup of the county of Cleveland into the current four unitary authorities of [[Middlesbrough (borough)|Middlesbrough]], [[Hartlepool (borough)|Hartlepool]], [[Redcar and Cleveland]] & [[Stockton-on-Tees (borough)|Stockton-on-Tees]]. With this latest reorganisation Thornaby-On-Tees became part of the borough of Stockton-on-Tees, however the town of Stockton-on-Tees itself is located on the north ("County Durham") side of the river, and is one of the most southerly towns Durham. The upshot of all this is that a significant proportion of Durham University is actually located within the [[Ceremonial counties of England|ceremonial county]] of [[North Yorkshire]], rather than County Durham. Adding to the confusion, plans exist to expand the campus on to the north bank of the River Tees, splitting the campus between the two ceremonial counties.-->
==21st century== In 2000 the new Graduate Society accommodation and offices at the Howlands Farm site were opened. The Graduate Society became [[Ustinov College]] in 2003.<ref name=Watson2007 />
By 2000 student numbers at University College, Stockton had reached 1,350, with plans to grow to 2,000 by 2003. It was bigger than any other Durham college, and set to keep growing. It was therefore decided to split UCS into two colleges that would be similar to the colleges in Durham City. The colleges were established as "shadow colleges" in October 2000. The two new colleges, named [[John Snow College|John Snow]] and [[Stephenson College, Durham|Stephenson]] (originally George Stephenson) after the [[John Snow (physician)|physician]] and the [[George Stephenson|engineer]], were formally established in September 2001, replacing UCS.<ref name=Stockton />
Also in 2001 the new [[medical school]] at UDSC (operating in association with the [[University of Newcastle upon Tyne]]) took in its first students – the first medics to join Durham since 1963 – and the [[Wolfson Research Institute]] opened.<ref name=Stockton /> In 2002, her [[golden jubilee]] year, the [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen]] granted UDSC the title of "Queen's Campus".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno=3163|title=A Queen’s Award for university campus in Stockton-on-Tees|date=8 May 2002|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref>
2002 saw the location for degree congregations moved from Durham Castle and Stockton Parish Church to Durham Cathedral, reducing the number of ceremonies from 24 (3 in Stockton) to a more manageable 12.<ref name=Stockton /> By 2003, 10 years after Stockton's opening, the university had 11,021 undergraduates, 17% of them on the Queen's Campus, and 2843 postgraduates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/about/facts/student/ |title=The University : Student Statistics - Durham University|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051207012000/http://www.dur.ac.uk/about/facts/student/|archive-date=7 December 2005|accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref> By 2013 this had increased to 12550 undergraduates, still with 17% in Stockton, and 4538 postgraduates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/resources/student.registry/statistics/summary/1.1summary/131-1.pdf|title=Summary of Student Numbers 2013/2014|accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref>
In 2003 the last single-sex college, [[St Mary's College, Durham|St. Mary's]], which was receiving fewer than 200 direct applications each year, voted to go mixed.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Castellum|title=Letter from the Master December 2003|volume=56|date=2004}}</ref> The first undergraduate men entered in 2005. In 2004 the university started the building of a new college next to Ustinov on the Howlands Farm site, as well as the construction of more accommodation for Ustinov. This opened in 2006 as [[Josephine Butler College]], the first completely new college to open in Durham itself since the 1970s, and the only purpose-built self-catering college within Durham.<ref name=Watson2007 />
2003 also saw the announcement of a controversial Strategic Improvement Plan. This included the closure of the departments of East Asian Studies and European Studies, the transfer if Linguistics to Newcastle (receiving their department of Religious Studies in return) and the movement of Middle East and Islamic Studies to become postgraduate-only, losing is undergraduate intake. The closures were expected to free up £8.7M for re-investment in more popular courses.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|title=The axe falls|date=22 July 2003|author=John Crace|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/jul/22/highereducation.cutsandclosures}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2003/dec/02/highereducation.administration|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|title=Durham and Newcastle to trade departments|date=2 December 2003|author=Donald MacLeod}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1436196/Durham-approves-studies-closure.html|title=Durham approves studies closure|author=Liz Lightfoot|date=16 July 2003|newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref> The closure, particularly of East Asian Studies, meet with opposition from the [[Foreign Office]], [[Durham City Council]] and the [[Japan Foundation]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]]|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1434933/Foreign-Office-joins-those-casting-doubt-on-Durham-closures.html|title=Foreign Office joins those casting doubt on Durham closures|author1=Richard Alleyne|author2=Liz Lightfoot|date=5 July 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[BBC]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/wear/3275219.stm|title=Row over university cuts|date=16 November 2003}}</ref> The cuts formed part of a tend in UK higher education at the time for small departments to be closed or merged, linked by [[The Guardian]] to "a combination of market forces and a strict funding regime".<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|title=The chemistry of closure|author=John Crace|date=23 March 2004|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2004/mar/23/highereducation.cutsandclosures}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=[[BBC News]]|title=University confirms subject cuts|date=20 December 2004|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/education/4105961.stm}}</ref>
In 2004 Durham was shortlisted for the [[Sunday Times University of the Year]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Another accolade recognises quality of teaching and learning at Durham|date=10 September 2004|accessdate=7 November 2015|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno=3708}}</ref> In 2005 it was shortlisted again and won the award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno=971|title=Durham is named ‘University of the Year’|date=30 September 2005|accessdate=7 November 2015}}</ref>
In 2005, the university unveiled a new [[logo]] (consisting of a stylised monochrome version of the coat of arms in [[Palatinate (colour)|palatinate purple]]) and [[logotype]], and adopted the trading name of "Durham University". The new branding caused much discussion, and Van Mildert JCR voted not to use the new name and logo.<ref>{{cite web|title=Van Mildert College JCR Minutes|url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/vm.jcr/dl.php?file=minutes-2005-05-08.pdf|date=8 May 2005|accessdate= 5 March 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629102002/http://www.dur.ac.uk/vm.jcr/dl.php?file=minutes-2005-05-08.pdf|archive-date=29 June 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|journal=Castellum|url=https://www.castlealumni.uk/files/castellum/Castellum%252058%2520(2005).pdf|title=Letter from the Master October 2005|date=2005|volume=58|page=4}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> The official name of the institution remains the University of Durham and no change was made to the actual coat of arms.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/about/trading_name/|title=Trading name|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
The [[Charities Act 2006]] necessitated a number of changes to the structure of the university's student bodies that went into effect in 2011. Previously [[exempt charity|exempt charities]], Student Unions were now to be regulated by the [[Charity Commission for England and Wales]]. The College JCRs were forced to decide whether to remain independent and become registered charities or to become part of the university. The university set up the "Durham Student Organisations Framework" for those JCRs (from the Maintained Colleges) becoming part of the university. Most eligible JCRs, along with Team Durham (previously the Durham University Athletics Union) and some other University-wide student bodies, chose to join this framework. [[Durham Students Union]], the JCRs of Grey, St Cuthbert's and Trevelyan, and the Ustinov GCR, became independent charities on 1 August 2011. Trevelyan JCR has since joined the framework (on 1 January 2014) and ceased to be an independent charity. St John's JCR also chose to become an independent charity rather than be merged with the College.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/ges/student_organisations/g_jcrs/historical/|title=Historical Status|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/ges/student_organisations/g_jcrs/|title=Current Status of the Student Organisations|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/ges/student_organisations/|title=Governance of Student Organisations|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/ges/student_organisations/team_durham/|title=Team Durham|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|title=Decision time for JCRs|date=7 March 2011|author=Sarah Ingrams|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=12465|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?regid=1155621&subid=0|title=John's Common Room|publisher=Charity Commission|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> The Act also removed exempt charity status from the colleges and halls in the universities of Cambridge and Durham and the colleges in the University of Oxford. This forced the St John's College, St Chad's College, and Ushaw College to become registered charities (the Maintained Colleges, being legally incorporated into the university and thus not having separate charitable status, were not affected).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stchads.ac.uk/college/documents/college-status/|title=Charitable and legal status|publisher=St Chad's College|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/about/governance/charitable_status/charities/|title=Charities linked to the University of Durham|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.opsi.gov.uk/si/si2010/em/uksiem_20100500_en.pdf|title=Explanatory Memorandum to the Charities Act 2006 (Changes in Exempt Charities) Order 2010|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://beta.charitycommission.gov.uk/charity-details/?regid=527408&subid=0|title=St Cuthbert's College, Ushaw|publisher=Charity Commission|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
In 2007 the campus cafeteria, "The Waterside Room", was renovated and now serves as the campus student bar. In addition to this facility both colleges at the campus benefit from their own college bars, managed centrally, however, and not by their JCRs. In 2007 the university announced that it had acquired an option on {{convert|4|acre|m2|adj=on}} of land in the 56-acre Northshore development on the north bank of the Tees, opposite the existing Queen's Campus site, along with plans to develop the academic structure at Queen's and the possibility of a new college.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno=5537|title= Durham University to extend Stockton campus|date=11 July 2007|publisher=Durham University|accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref> In 2012 it was announced that after a four-year delay due to the state of the economy, the Northshore development was proceeding, including plans from the university for academic facilities and a 500-bed residential development.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/new-plans-flagship-northshore-development-3670361|title= New plans for flagship Northshore development site|newspaper=The Gazette|date=10 September 2012|author=Mike Blackburn|accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref> The Queen's Campus cafeteria, was reopened after renovation in February 2008 to serve as a dining room, the Waterside Restaurant, used two days a week by each of the two Queen's Campus colleges,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/catering.queens/collegesevening/|title=Colleges' Evening Dining|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> and their joint college bar, the Waterside Bar.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/stephenson/facilities/bar/|title=Bar|publisher=Stephenson College|accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref> On 14 May 2009 the [[Infinity Bridge]] was opened, linking the Queen's Campus and the Teasdale business park to the Northshore development.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rediscoverstockton.co.uk/riverside/stocktons-bridges/|title=Stockton's Bridges|accessdate=2 November 2015|publisher=Stockton-on-Tees Borough Council}}</ref> In November 2015 it was announced that the university would not be renewing its option on development of the Northshore site and would be holding a "wide and robust consultation process" on the future of the Queen's Campus.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|title=Future of Queen’s Campus to undergo consultation|date=4 November 2015|author=Ryan Gould|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=63721|accessdate=5 November 2015}}</ref>
In Durham City, development was concentrated in the Elvet Hill area, leading to fears that Durham was moving away from the city centre and becoming a "campus university".<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|title=Fears of "Campus University" grow|date=27 October 2011|author=Rowena Caine|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=16146}}</ref> The Calman Learning Centre on the Mountjoy Site opened in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/cis/theatres/calman/|title=Calman Learning Centre|accessdate=3 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119195304/https://www.dur.ac.uk/cis/theatres/calman/|archivedate=19 November 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This was followed by Anthropology moving to Mountjoy and Economics moving to the Business School.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|title=Higgins insists the University is not moving|date=15 November 2011|author=Rowena Caine|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=17046}}</ref> In 2012 the new Palatine Centre was opened on the Mountjoy Site, housing the Law school and the university administration and an extension to the Bill Bryson library on the Mountjoy Site was opened.<ref name=Palatine>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno=15646|title=Durham invests in enhanced student experience with new Palatine Centre|date=24 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/library/developments/mainlibrary/|title=Bill Bryson Library Developments|accessdate=3 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119195208/https://www.dur.ac.uk/library/developments/mainlibrary/|archivedate=19 November 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, the university also spent £10 million on the refurbishment of the Palace Green Library between 2009 and 2014,<ref name=Palatine /> creating new galleries and a special exhibitions space.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/library/developments/palacegreen/|title=Palace Green Library Redevelopments|accessdate=3 November 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119204153/https://www.dur.ac.uk/library/developments/palacegreen/|archivedate=19 November 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In 2006 the university partnered with [[University of Manchester|Manchester]] and [[University of Edinburgh|Edinburgh]] to create the [[Centre for Advanced Study of the Arab World]] with funding from the UK government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.casaw.ac.uk/about-us/|title=About Us|publisher=[[Centre for Advanced Study of the Arab World]]|accessdate=7 November 2015}}</ref> In 2008 the university created the [[Sharjah Chair in Islamic Law and Finance]] with an endowment from Sheikh [[Sultan bin Muhammad Al-Qasimi]], Emir of [[Sharjah]]. This followed an earlier donation in 1999 by the Emir, which funded the construction of the Al Qasimi building (opened in 2003).<ref>{{cite web|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731092928/http://www.socialcohesion.co.uk/files/1238334646_1.pdf|archive-date=31 July 2009|url=http://www.socialcohesion.co.uk/files/1238334646_1.pdf|title=A Degree of Influence|author=Robin Simcox|publisher=The Centre for Social Cohesion|date=2009|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref> The decision to accept funding from Al-Qasimi was criticised as spreading "extremist ideas" by Anthony Glees, director of [[Brunel University]]'s Centre for Intelligence and Security Studies, who had previously claimed a number of British universities had been infiltrated by Islamic extremists.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1584954/Extremism-fear-over-Islam-studies-donations.html|title='Extremism' fear over Islam studies donations|date=13 April 2008|author=Ben Leach|newspaper=[[Sunday Telegraph]]}}</ref>
In 2008 Durham launched the Centre for Catholic Studies in collaboration with the [[Diocese of Hexham and Newcastle]], including the [[Bede Professor of Catholic Theology]], the first chair in Catholic theology at a secular University in the UK.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2008/mar/05/highereducation.research|title=Durham to launch centre for Catholic studies|author=Liz Ford|date=5 March 2008|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> As the Bede Professor serves as theological advisor to the Bishop of Hexham and Newcastle, the post is (following legal advice) restricted to practising Catholics, but the holder is not required to obtain the ''mandatum''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teologhe.org/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/Bede-Professor-of-Catholic-Theology-Advert.pdf|title=Bede Professor of Catholic Theology|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Tablet]]|date=29 May 2010|author=Paul Murray|title=Faith, theology and the secular cloister|pages=12–14|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100619222626/http://americamagazine.org/articles/Tablet_murray.pdf|url=http://americamagazine.org/articles/Tablet_murray.pdf|archive-date=19 June 2010}}</ref> However, in 2011 [[Ushaw College]] closed as a Catholic seminary.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=Catholic Herald|url=http://www.catholicherald.co.uk/news/2011/02/03/ushaw-college-to-close-in-june/|date=3 February 2011|author=Mark Greaves|title=Ushaw College to close in June}}</ref> It remains (as of 2015) a Licensed Hall of Residence in the university's statutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/university.calendar/volumei/statutes/| accessdate=2 November 2015|title=University Statutes}}</ref> Parts of Ushaw are currently used by [[Durham University Business School]] and [[Josephine Butler College]], as well as the Centre for Catholic Studies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/business/programmes/masters/marketing/marketing/location/|title=Location|accessdate=2 November 2015|publisher=[[Durham University Business School]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/butler.college/postgraduate/accommodation/ushaw/|title=Josephine Butler College at Ushaw|accessdate=2 November 2015|publisher=[[Josephine Butler College]]}}</ref> The Ushaw library has been integrated with the Durham University library, and the university is investigating the possibility of Ushaw becoming home to a new university college.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/10885938.Historic_Catholic_seminary_could_become_Durham_University_college/|newspaper=[[Northern Echo]]|title=Historic Catholic seminary could become Durham University college|author=Mark Tallentire|date=18 December 2013}}</ref> In 2014 a £2M endowment was secured to establish the St Hilda Chair in Catholic Social Thought and Practice.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/theology.religion/about/news/?itemno=21544|title=St Hilda Chair in Catholic Social Thought and Practice: Dr Mark Hayes confirmed as inaugural appointee|date=24 June 2014|accessdate=7 November 2015}}</ref> In October 2015 the [[Catholic National Library]] moved to Durham University.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.catholicherald.co.uk/news/2015/10/22/catholic-national-library-moves-to-durham-university/|newspaper=Catholic Herald|title=Catholic National Library moves to Durham University|date=22 October 2015}}</ref>
[[File:Dun Cow Lane.jpg|thumb|right|The university's Department of Theology is partly housed in buildings on [[Dun Cow]] Lane]] In July 2009, [[Tony Blair]], the former [[British Prime Minister]], announced a strategic partnership with Durham University, following [[Yale University]] and the [[National University of Singapore]], to create a [[Faith and Globalisation Network of Universities|global network]] of twelve leading research universities for delivering his Faith and Globalization Initiative in association with [[Tony Blair Faith Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Tony Blair foundation partnership with Durham University |url=http://www.tonyblairfaithfoundation.org/2009/07/parnership-with-durham-univers.html |publisher=tonyblairfaithfoundation |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090724165135/http://www.tonyblairfaithfoundation.org/2009/07/parnership-with-durham-univers.html |archivedate=24 July 2009 |deadurl=unfit }}</ref>
Between 2010 and 2012, Durham was criticised for accepting a number of donations from controversial sources. On 28 January 2010, Durham hosted a seminar sponsored by the government of [[Iran]], which attracted protests and coverage in the national press.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/feb/10/iranian-funding-durham-university-boycott|title=Iranian tensions shake Durham's ivory towers|author=Ian Black|date=10 February 2010}}</ref> In February 2011, the Durham Student newspaper [[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]] broke the story that a [[WikiLeaks]] cable revealed that a series of Iranian seminars at Durham had been funded by the [[US State Department]] as "political cover" for contacts with Iran.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|date=8 February 2011|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=10679|title=Durham University engulfed in Wikileaks allegations|author1=Daniel Johnson|author2=Jack Battersby}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|work=[[BBC]]|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/education-12908507|title=Durham University defends accepting funds from Iran|author=Simon Cox|date=31 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2011/feb/10/wikileaks-durham-university-iran-us-embassy|title=WikiLeaks reveals degree of Durham University's involvement in Iran|author=Ian Black|date=10 February 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> Vice-Chancellor [[Chris Higgins (academic)|Chris Higgins]] claimed in an interview with Palatinate that the funding had not been deliberately hidden and would have been revealed if anyone had asked, but accepted that more should have been done to let participants know the source of the funding.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=12008|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|title=Vice-chancellor defends Durham’s ethical funding policy|date=3 March 2011|author1=Jack Battersby|author2=Daniel Johnson}}</ref> In March 2011, [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] MP [[Robert Halfon]] accused Durham of accepting "blood money" from the Iranian government and launched an [[Early Day Motion]] (which attracted no other signatories) calling for a Government enquiry.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=12659|title=MP accuses Durham of accepting "blood money"|date=12 March 2011|author=Sarah Ingrams}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/edm/2010-12/1563|title=Links Between Iran And Durham University|publisher=[[British Parliament]]|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref> Later that month it was revealed that the university had accepted a £2.5M donation from the Prime Minister of [[Kuwait]], Sheikh [[Nasser Al-Sabah]], to endow the [[Sheikh Nasser Bin Muhammad Al-Sabah Professor in International Relations|Sheikh Nasser al-Mohammad Al-Sabah Chair]] and a related research programme in global security,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/alsabah/sabahchair/|title=The Sheikh Nasser al-Mohammad al-Sabah Chair|accessdate=9 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=12796|title=Kuwait PM to donate £2.5m to Durham|date=30 March 2011|author=Daniel Johnson|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120914094130/http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=12796|archivedate=14 September 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> leading to further criticism.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.new.spectator.co.uk/2011/04/shaky-dealings-are-damaging-the-reputation-of-britains-universities/|title=Shaky dealings are damaging the reputation of Britain’s universities|newspaper=[[The Spectator]]|author=David Blackburn|date=1 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151119171502/http://blogs.new.spectator.co.uk/2011/04/shaky-dealings-are-damaging-the-reputation-of-britains-universities/|archivedate=19 November 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
This was overshadowed a few weeks later by the news that Durham had accepted £125,000 from [[British American Tobacco]] towards an appeal for scholarships for Afghan women from [[Kabul University]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.co.uk/news/north-east-news/durham-university-criticised-accepting-tobacco-4432126|newspaper=The Journal|title=Durham University criticised for accepting tobacco cash|date=17 May 2011|author=Ruth Lawson}}</ref> The university claimed that "The BAT donation was accepted following careful consideration by the University Executive Committee (UEC) in line with its Gift Acceptance Policy".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-tyne-13422170|newspaper=[[BBC]]|title=Durham University defends British American Tobacco cash|date=17 May 2011}}</ref> However, [[Cancer Research UK]] claimed that "The death and disease caused by BAT's products dwarf this small award" and accused Durham of breaching the [[World Health Organization]]'s [[Framework Convention on Tobacco Control]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2011/jun/07/durham-university-tobacco-funding-afghan-award|title=Furore over Durham's tobacco funding for Afghan scholarship|author=Lucy Tobin|date=7 June 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref>
In July 2012, it was reported by [[WikiLeaks]] that an aide to Syrian President [[Bashar al-Assad]] was to receive a PhD from Durham. Halfon again attacked the university, which responded with a statement saying that students were admitted and awarded degrees solely on merit and denying "any formal or active links with the Syrian government".<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Durham Times]]|url=http://www.durhamtimes.co.uk/news/9805439.University_denies_Syrian_links/?ref=rss|title=University denies Syrian links|date=9 July 2012}}</ref> In September the al-Sabah programme was officially launched in the presence of Sheikh Nasser al-Sabah.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Dialogue|publisher=Durham University |url=http://issuu.com/communicationsoffice/docs/dialogue_issue_26/7|page=7|volume=26|title=Nassar Al-Mohammad Al-Sabah Middle East Security Research Programme|date=November 2012}}</ref> However, since pledging his donation the Sheikh had been forced to resign as Prime Minister of Kuwait in late 2011 over allegations his government had misappropriated state funds. Despite his being cleared of the allegations by a judicial tribunal in May 2012, this drew further protests from Halfon and links were drawn by the [[Daily Telegraph]] between this and the acceptance by the [[London School of Economics]] of donations from [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi|Saif al-Islam]], son of [[Libya]]n leader Colonel [[Ghadaffi]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Durham University's £2.5m Kuwaiti gift 'astonishing', says Conservative MP|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/9574061/Durham-Universitys-2.5m-Kuwaiti-gift-astonishing-says-Conservative-MP.html|date=1 October 2012|author=Andrew Marszal|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]}}</ref>
In November 2012 it was revealed by the [[Times Higher Education]] that the university's senior management had overruled the Ethics Committee to accept the donation from British American Tobacco. It was also revealed that the university and British American Tobacco had agreed not to publicise the donation for fear of attracting criticism and that the executive committee had been split over accepting the money. The Times Higher Education revealed there had been resignations from the university's council over the issue and asked if the resignation of the university's registrar in June 2012 was also linked.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Times Higher Education]]|title=Tobacco gift to Durham caused turmoil at the top|author=David Matthews|date=8 November 2012|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/news/tobacco-gift-to-durham-caused-turmoil-at-the-top/421718.article}}</ref>
In 2012 Durham, along with three other universities, accepted an invitation to join the [[Russell Group]] and left the [[1994 Group]].<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|url=https://www.theguardian.com/education/2012/mar/12/russell-group-four-more-universities|date=12 March 2012|title=Russell Group extends membership to four more universities|author=Jessica Shepherd}}</ref>
In July 2012, Council endorsed a "residential accommodation strategy" for 2012–2020. This sets a target of 50–70% of students housed in University accommodation and predicted growth in student numbers to 14,000 in Durham City and 2,500 at the Queen's Campus by 2015/16 and to 15,300 in Durham City and 3,400 at the Queen's Campus by 2019/20. With 5,700 beds in Durham and 900 in Stockton for 2012/13, meeting the accommodation targets would require (in Durham) 1,250 new beds by 2015 and 1,950 by 2019 and (in Stockton) 730 new beds by 2015 and 1,150 by 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/resources/estates/documents/DurhamUniversity-ResidentialAccommodationStrategy2012-2020.ppt|archive-url=https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20160109090034/https://www.dur.ac.uk/resources/estates/documents/DurhamUniversity-ResidentialAccommodationStrategy2012-2020.ppt|dead-url=yes|archive-date=9 January 2016|title=Residential Accommodation Strategy 2012–2020|publisher=Durham University|accessdate=3 November 2015}}</ref>
In the same year Council approved plans for a new 500 room college, with the preferred site being the former golf course at [[Mount Oswald]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=32452|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|date=12 December 2012|author=Harriet Line|title=New college plans revealed}}</ref> In 2014 the university acquired the land on Mount Oswald and entered into a contract with the developers to build accommodation for 1000 students.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=48958|newspaper=Palatinate |title=University to build additional 1,000 beds on Mount Oswald site|date=5 August 2014|author=Justin Villamil}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.banksgroup.co.uk/durham-university-reaches-agreement-with-the-banks-group-for-sale-of-land-at-mount-oswald/|publisher=The Banks Group|title=Durham university reaches agreement with the Banks Group for sale of land at Mount Oswald|date=6 August 2014|accessdate=2 November 2015}}</ref>
Also in 2012, the [[Church of England]] announced that Durham had been chosen as the partner university for the [[Common Award]] for ministerial training. This scheme provides for a common suite of awards, validated by Durham, for all ordinands in the Church of England and its partner churches from September 2014.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Church Times]]|title=Durham University to validate C of E ordination training|author=Madeleine Davies|date=29 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.churchofengland.org/clergy-office-holders/ministry/ministerial-education-and-development/common-awards-in-theology,-ministry-and-mission/about-the-common-awards.aspx|title=About the Common Awards|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
The [[Methodist Connexion]] decided in 2012 that our would be centralising ministerial training in two centres, meaning the withdrawal of ministerial trainees from the Wesley Study Centre, with the last ministerial candidates graduating in 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dur.ac.uk/wsc.online/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Wesley-Study-Centre-Insert-Nov-12.pdf|title=Wesley Study Centre Newsletter Insert Autumn 2012|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> It was announced in 2014 that the Centre would be remaining open as a research and postgraduate education centre.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://community.dur.ac.uk/wsc.online/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Wesley-Study-Centre-Newsletter-Easter-2014_WEB.pdf|title=Wesley Study Centre Newsletter Spring 2014|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref>
In 2013, the [[Michael Ramsey]] Chair in Anglican Studies (not to be confused with [[University of Kent|Kent]]'s Michael Ramsey Chair in Modern Theology) was established in partnership with Durham Cathedral. This, like the [[Van Mildert Professor of Divinity]] is a canon professorship, with the holder being a non-residentiary canon of the Cathedral. The holder is not (unlike the Van Mildert Professor, who is a residentiary canon<ref>{{cite web|url=http://scholarshipdb.net/jobs-in-United-Kingdom/Van-Mildert-Canon-Professor-Of-Divinity-Durham-University=aWmQucdx5BGULgAlkGUTnw.html|title=Van Mildert Canon Professor of Divinity|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref>) required to be ordained but is required, as a member of the college of canons, to be "a communicant member of the Church of England or the Anglican Communion, or of any other member church of Churches Together in Britain and Ireland (which includes most Christian denominations), or of a church in communion with such a church".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://scholarshipdb.net/jobs-in-United-Kingdom/Michael-Ramsey-Professor-Of-Anglican-Studies-Durham-University=dS_He8dx5BGULgAlkGUTnw.html|title=Michael Ramsey Professor of Anglican Studies|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/theology.religion/about/news/?itemno=19321|title=Ramsey Chair in Anglican Studies|date=21 November 2013|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref> The first Ramsey Professor, Michael Snape, was appointed in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/theology.religion/about/news/?itemno=23733|title=Two new Canon Professors appointed|date=12 February 2015|accessdate=8 November 2015}}</ref>
In 2014 Durham established the [[UNESCO]] Chair in Archaeological Ethics and Practice in Cultural Heritage, the first UNESCO chair in Durham and the thirteenth in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bajrfed.co.uk/bajrpress/durham-establishes-its-first-unesco-chair-in-archaeological-ethics-and-practice-in-cultural-heritage/|title=Durham establishes its first UNESCO Chair in Archaeological Ethics and Practice in Cultural Heritage|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=7 November 2015}}</ref>
In 2014 Durham won the Times and Sunday Times Sports University of the Year 2015,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/news/newsitem/?itemno=22113|title=Durham University named as Times and Sunday Times Sports University of the Year 2015|date=19 September 2014|accessdate=7 November 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[The Times]]|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/undergraduate/life/times-sport-uni-2015/|title=Fit for purpose: success on the field of play and in community outreach programmes puts Team Durham ahead of the pack|date=21 September 2014|author=Zone Thomas|access-date=7 November 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305140224/https://www.dur.ac.uk/undergraduate/life/times-sport-uni-2015/#|archive-date=5 March 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and in 2015 it was shortlisted for the third time for the [[Sunday Times University of the Year|Times and Sunday Times University of the Year]] 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dur.ac.uk/research/news/item/?itemno=25644|title=Durham secures 5th in Good University Guide|date=1 September 2015|accessdate=7 November 2015}}</ref>
In November 2015 it was announced that the University would not be renewing its option on development of the site on the north bank of the Tees and would be holding a consultation on the future of the Queen's Campus.<ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]|title=Future of Queen’s Campus to undergo consultation|date=4 November 2015|author=Ryan Gould|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/?p=63721|accessdate=5 November 2015}}</ref> In February 2016 it was announced that the university's working group had recommended moving the colleges and academic activities currently at the Queen's Campus to Durham City from September 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/durham-university-considering-withdrawing-medical-10950734|work=Gazette Live|title=Durham University considering withdrawing medical school from Stockton|date=25 February 2016|author=James Cain}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/university-continues-to-consult-on-the-future-of-queen’s-campus/|title=University continues to consult on the future of Queen’s Campus|date=10 March 2016|author=Charlie Taylor-Kroll|newspaper=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]}}</ref> This decision was confirmed in May 2016, with the School of Medicine, Pharmacy and Health being transferred to [[Newcastle University]] on 1 August 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/tyne-tees/2016-07-13/durham-university-to-move-school-of-medicine-pharmacy-and-health-out-of-teesside/|title=Durham University to move school of medicine, pharmacy and health out of Teesside|date=13 July 2016|work=[[itv.com]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/durham-university-confirms-plans-pull-11314325|title=Durham University confirms plans to pull academic and college-based activities from Stockton |date=10 May 2016|author=James Cain|work=GazetteLive}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://my.ncl.ac.uk/staff/nuconnections/item/transfer-of-school-of-medicine-pharmacy-and-health-to-newcastle1|title=Transfer of School of Medicine, Pharmacy and Health to Newcastle|accessdate=7 August 2017|date=10 July 2017|publisher=Newcastle University}}</ref> The Queen's Campus is to remain part of the University and will be repurposed as an International Study Centre, to be run by [[Study Group International|Study Group]].<ref name="Queen's ISC">{{cite news|url=http://www.palatinate.org.uk/queens-campus-to-house-new-centre-for-international-students/|title= Queen’s Campus to house new centre for international students|date=30 January 2017|author= Eugene Smith|work=[[Palatinate (newspaper)|Palatinate]]}}</ref>
